content: The Fat Tax Is Real—and It’s Getting Worse Inflated prices, surcharges, and limited employment opportunities are expanding the wealth gap between fat and thin Your Fat Friend Blocked Unblock Follow Following Apr 9 Credit: CasarsaGuru/Getty Images I am booking a work trip across the country. It should be a simple task: find a flight at a reasonable time, for a reasonable price, and purchase it. But this otherwise mundane task isn’t so simple for me, so I brace myself to pay double—or more—to reach my final destination. I am fat, and this is one of the many prices I pay for it. My destination is a new one, and there are no nonstop flights between here and there, so I will have to change flights, and my itinerary will require me to fly on two different airlines. That means researching the frustratingly inconsistent “customer of size” policies for multiple carriers to find out who will allow me to stay on the flight and for what price. Some airlines allow fat customers to purchase two seats in advance, but may sell the second seat without that fat passenger’s knowledge or consent. Others will simply wait for a fat passenger to arrive, then inform them they’ll be charged for a second seat at the day-of price, regardless of availability. The policies vary greatly from airline to airline , and only the worst of the bunch fly from my hometown to my final destination. I research airlines intently and find a transfer flight with one whose policy may charge me more to fly, but makes no mention of kicking me off the flight. Ticket agents and flight crew are rarely trained on how to enforce “customer of size” policies, so what comes to pass remains a gamble. If the flight crew is thoughtful and kind, if they’ve thought about what it’s like to fly as a fat person, I may emerge unscathed. If they are not, I will be humiliated and charged for the privilege. I feel my heartbeat gaining steam, a heavy locomotive chugging its way up a steep incline. I pour myself a drink and try not to think about boarding the flight. Next, I look at ticket prices. A standard ticket to my final destination will cost $390, which my employer will pay. To ensure my ability to retain the seat I purchase, I’ll need to either buy a second seat or purchase a first-class seat, both of which are costs I’ll need to shoulder on my own. A second seat will cost an additional $780 in unplanned expenses, round trip. A first-class seat will cost $3,014 more. I book my departing flight and give myself a break to look at our lodging for the meeting. I find myself relying on credit cards to cover these basic expenses, garnering debt I never wanted for a cost my thinner colleagues don’t bear. I look at the hotel rooms to confirm I’ll have room to move around the bed, room to get into the shower. I look online for accessibility information, which is hard to find as it is and rarely includes information that reflects the needs of fat people. My search comes up short. A friend regularly pays extra for hotel rooms with wider capacity bathtubs and toilets that she knows will bear her weight, usually netting an additional cost of $100-$300, depending on the length of her stay. I remind myself to be grateful: These are not problems I face, and I won’t have to rent a car for this trip—which means I also won’t have to pay for an upgrade to ensure I’ll fit into the vehicle provided. I begin searching for a return flight. In order to travel on an airline I know is safe, I will need to be at the airport for a 5:30 a.m. flight. This will require me either to miss a full day of this mandatory work meeting or pay for an additional night of lodging out of my own pocket. I am already down $390 of my own money, with at least another $390 to go. The thought of another $150 for lodging turns my stomach, as does explaining to colleagues why I’d be leaving early. I opt for the lodging. The privilege of taking this work trip—one that’s mandatory, and for which costs are assumed to be covered—is now $930. I factor in the cost of checking a bag—$25 each way, since larger clothing takes up more space—and come to a grand total of $980. I congratulate myself on falling short of the usual expense: $1,000 in out-of-pocket costs. Over time, these costs add up. I find myself relying on credit cards to cover these basic expenses, garnering debt I never wanted for a cost my thinner colleagues don’t bear. But it isn’t much of a choice at all: Pay what’s been called the “fat tax” or miss essential work events. Pay or stop advancing. Pay or lose my job. L ater in the week, I am daydreaming about patio furniture for the summer, hoping I can find something affordable at a discount chain store or website. But the fat tax finds me there too. The majority of Adirondack chairs, while available for under $100 in some cases, are built with a weight limit of 200 pounds. Those manufactured with higher weight capacities will cost $300 or $400—a significant markup over the cost of materials to build them. No, the fat tax isn’t restricted to travel. It extends to furniture of all kinds, rarely available to those of us over 300 pounds without paying triple the price of thinner people. Folding chairs, $30 for thin people, can run fat people $150. Bed frames that support our bodies are available, but only for thousands of dollars . Exercise equipment, too, is largely made for thinner people. Paradoxically, we are even financially shut out of the getting in shape that is constantly suggested to us. Cars, too, are a challenge, and information about their weight capacity, seat width, and maximum distance from the steering wheel are rarely made available. Often, fat people are required to buy larger cars with lower gas mileage, required to shoulder the cost of more car than we’d want and more fuel than we’d like. Those of us who don’t drive will have to pay more for bicycles that will bear us, since so many bikes only support 150 to 200 pounds . Even clothing is a challenge, and ethically made clothing is almost entirely out of the question when it comes to plus and extended plus sizes. Even budget staples like Old Navy have dramatic price gaps. A pair of basic jeans in size 18 from the straight size women’s section costs $27 . Meanwhile, the same size from their plus section costs $45 (and, in many parts of the country, can only be purchased online). New Look , H&M, Boohoo, and Asos have similar practices, regularly charging dramatically higher prices for the plus size version of the same article of clothing. Jewelry, especially rings and bracelets, offers an extremely limited selection, often requiring a costly special order in fine jewelry and extraordinarily limited options for costume jewelry. But fat people don’t just pay more—we also make less than our thinner counterparts. The fat tax finds us in health care too. If we see a doctor who doesn’t dismiss our symptoms out of hand, brushing them off with a simple “just lose weight,” many of us will be required to seek care out-of-network and pay out-of-pocket just to access the same health care as thinner people. Even if we get lucky and find a doctor in our network, equipment like MRIs and CT scanners are built for thin people. Often, fat patients shoulder the cost of finding, and traveling to, facilities that have equipment that fit our bodies. Fat people with disabilities pay hundreds more for wheelchairs, walkers, and crutches that support their fat bodies. And fat people who become pregnant may be saddled with the additional cost of an abortion or prenatal care because most emergency contraception doesn’t reliably work on bodies over 176 pounds . These, it seems, are the costs of living in the only body I have ever had. For many fat people, no matter how healthy our habits, life insurance will be out of the question, leaving us with fewer ways to care for our loved ones when we are gone. And they will face the fat tax too. Because even burying a fat person costs more, with standard size coffins running $2,000-$3,000, while plus size caskets cost up to $5,000 apiece . But fat people don’t just pay more—we also make less than our thinner counterparts. Some studies show that fat people make $2,500 less than thin people each year. Others show that a woman who is just 13 pounds over her BMI-recommended weight makes $9,000 less annually than her thin colleagues. And when broken out by gender, the fat pay gap widens dramatically . Multiple federal circuit court decisions have upheld employers’ right to both weigh employees and to fire them solely because of their size. Just three years ago, courts told 22 former “Borgata Babes”—casino servers who were subjected to random weigh-ins and suspensions for weight gain—that their employer’s policies were just fine , allowable under state and federal law, which does not provide even basic legal protections against size-based bias. Even the most overt size-based discrimination is perfectly legal in the United States. Those of us fortunate and privileged enough to find steady employment with decent pay can be regularly set back by the costs of retention and advancement: second airline seats, checked bags, rental car upgrades, and more. These, it seems, are the costs of living in the only body I have ever had. L ike so many conversations about fatness, requesting the accommodations I need feels like a fait accompli . My experience has been so reliably disappointing and isolating that I struggle to imagine anything changing. Every time I think of approaching human resources, I watch a rudimentary flip-book animation in my mind’s eye: My colleagues will happily take my requested meeting. We will talk pleasantly for a few minutes, all warmth and kindness. I will watch their faces fall as they come to understand what I am asking them for. And then, they will fall into the same trap as so many before them, ending the conversation with some variation on a callous phrase, cruel in its simplicity: “If you don’t like it, just lose weight.” Just . As if their 10-pound New Year’s resolution obeyed the same rules my 240-pound loss would, should I try to meet my BMI-recommended weight. Just . As if it were that easy to cut my body in half. As if it would take fewer than five years of uninterrupted and extreme dieting that would ultimately result in major weight gain and permanently damage my metabolism in the long term . As if diets even work—they don’t; 97% of diets fail . As if women my size had even a 1% chance of becoming thin. (We don’t— only 0.8% of very fat women will reach their BMI-recommended weight in their lifetime.) Just. As if weight loss surgeries were covered by health insurance and wouldn’t cost $25K, plus the cost of follow-up procedures to remove excess skin. As if those surgeries didn’t have terrifying complications and change the way a person eats forever. As if this were a reasonable intervention into the fat tax—pay tens of thousands of dollars in surgery costs to pay the same rate as everyone else for clothing, travel, furniture. Just. As if they knew. As I write this, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 70% of Americans are “overweight” or “obese.” If we were in Congress, we would comprise a supermajority. If we were test scores, we would be a passing grade. We are not a niche market, nor can we be saved by the casual dismissal of just . Overwhelmingly, the costs facing us are leveled by major corporations whose industries are growing, costs decreasing, and profit margins increasing. Airlines are expected to make $35.5 billion in profits this year, while the apparel industry is worth $292 billion . Their bottom lines are as strong as ever, even as so many of them seek solely to serve 30% of their potential customers—those whose thin bodies afford them the privilege of service. Corporate profits are doing fine, and they aren’t the question here. Will we build that brave new world with the fat people we know and love? The question here is the degree to which we are willing to create and exploit a growing wealth gap facing fat people across the country and around the world. Our fat friends and family already work less, earn less, and pay more, even for basic necessities. We are more likely to be fired, more likely to be overcharged, and more likely to face economic insecurity than our thinner counterparts. Are we willing to tell our fat friends, family, neighbors, and co-workers that their systemic economic disenfranchisement is unavoidable, that the fat tax they pay is some natural consequence of their skin ? Or will we build a world that works for all of us? Will we work to level the playing field that has been so skewed based on how our bodies look? Or will we sit idly by as fat people make less and less, build more and more debt, and lag behind our thinner peers, regardless of our skills, character, and work ethic? Will we build that brave new world with the fat people we know and love? Or will we hang them out to dry for the simple, dismissive brush-off of just?
title_html: The Fat Tax Is Real—and It’s Getting Worse
html:
Homepage
Homepage
Sign inGet started
  • Body
  • Mind
  • Heart
  • Hands
  • Eyes
  • Soul
  • About

The Fat Tax Is Real—and It’s Getting Worse

Inflated prices, surcharges, and limited employment opportunities are expanding the wealth gap between fat and thin

Your Fat Friend
Apr 9

I am booking a work trip across the country. It should be a simple task: find a flight at a reasonable time, for a reasonable price, and purchase it. But this otherwise mundane task isn’t so simple for me, so I brace myself to pay double—or more—to reach my final destination. I am fat, and this is one of the many prices I pay for it.

My destination is a new one, and there are no nonstop flights between here and there, so I will have to change flights, and my itinerary will require me to fly on two different airlines. That means researching the frustratingly inconsistent “customer of size” policies for multiple carriers to find out who will allow me to stay on the flight and for what price. Some airlines allow fat customers to purchase two seats in advance, but may sell the second seat without that fat passenger’s knowledge or consent. Others will simply wait for a fat passenger to arrive, then inform them they’ll be charged for a second seat at the day-of price, regardless of availability. The policies vary greatly from airline to airline, and only the worst of the bunch fly from my hometown to my final destination.

I research airlines intently and find a transfer flight with one whose policy may charge me more to fly, but makes no mention of kicking me off the flight. Ticket agents and flight crew are rarely trained on how to enforce “customer of size” policies, so what comes to pass remains a gamble. If the flight crew is thoughtful and kind, if they’ve thought about what it’s like to fly as a fat person, I may emerge unscathed. If they are not, I will be humiliated and charged for the privilege. I feel my heartbeat gaining steam, a heavy locomotive chugging its way up a steep incline. I pour myself a drink and try not to think about boarding the flight.

Next, I look at ticket prices. A standard ticket to my final destination will cost $390, which my employer will pay. To ensure my ability to retain the seat I purchase, I’ll need to either buy a second seat or purchase a first-class seat, both of which are costs I’ll need to shoulder on my own. A second seat will cost an additional $780 in unplanned expenses, round trip. A first-class seat will cost $3,014 more. I book my departing flight and give myself a break to look at our lodging for the meeting.

I find myself relying on credit cards to cover these basic expenses, garnering debt I never wanted for a cost my thinner colleagues don’t bear.

I look at the hotel rooms to confirm I’ll have room to move around the bed, room to get into the shower. I look online for accessibility information, which is hard to find as it is and rarely includes information that reflects the needs of fat people. My search comes up short. A friend regularly pays extra for hotel rooms with wider capacity bathtubs and toilets that she knows will bear her weight, usually netting an additional cost of $100-$300, depending on the length of her stay. I remind myself to be grateful: These are not problems I face, and I won’t have to rent a car for this trip—which means I also won’t have to pay for an upgrade to ensure I’ll fit into the vehicle provided.

I begin searching for a return flight. In order to travel on an airline I know is safe, I will need to be at the airport for a 5:30 a.m. flight. This will require me either to miss a full day of this mandatory work meeting or pay for an additional night of lodging out of my own pocket. I am already down $390 of my own money, with at least another $390 to go. The thought of another $150 for lodging turns my stomach, as does explaining to colleagues why I’d be leaving early. I opt for the lodging.

The privilege of taking this work trip—one that’s mandatory, and for which costs are assumed to be covered—is now $930. I factor in the cost of checking a bag—$25 each way, since larger clothing takes up more space—and come to a grand total of $980. I congratulate myself on falling short of the usual expense: $1,000 in out-of-pocket costs.

Over time, these costs add up. I find myself relying on credit cards to cover these basic expenses, garnering debt I never wanted for a cost my thinner colleagues don’t bear. But it isn’t much of a choice at all: Pay what’s been called the “fat tax” or miss essential work events. Pay or stop advancing. Pay or lose my job.

Later in the week, I am daydreaming about patio furniture for the summer, hoping I can find something affordable at a discount chain store or website. But the fat tax finds me there too. The majority of Adirondack chairs, while available for under $100 in some cases, are built with a weight limit of 200 pounds. Those manufactured with higher weight capacities will cost $300 or $400—a significant markup over the cost of materials to build them.

No, the fat tax isn’t restricted to travel. It extends to furniture of all kinds, rarely available to those of us over 300 pounds without paying triple the price of thinner people. Folding chairs, $30 for thin people, can run fat people $150. Bed frames that support our bodies are available, but only for thousands of dollars. Exercise equipment, too, is largely made for thinner people. Paradoxically, we are even financially shut out of the getting in shape that is constantly suggested to us.

Cars, too, are a challenge, and information about their weight capacity, seat width, and maximum distance from the steering wheel are rarely made available. Often, fat people are required to buy larger cars with lower gas mileage, required to shoulder the cost of more car than we’d want and more fuel than we’d like. Those of us who don’t drive will have to pay more for bicycles that will bear us, since so many bikes only support 150 to 200 pounds.

Even clothing is a challenge, and ethically made clothing is almost entirely out of the question when it comes to plus and extended plus sizes. Even budget staples like Old Navy have dramatic price gaps. A pair of basic jeans in size 18 from the straight size women’s section costs $27. Meanwhile, the same size from their plus section costs $45 (and, in many parts of the country, can only be purchased online). New Look, H&M, Boohoo, and Asos have similar practices, regularly charging dramatically higher prices for the plus size version of the same article of clothing. Jewelry, especially rings and bracelets, offers an extremely limited selection, often requiring a costly special order in fine jewelry and extraordinarily limited options for costume jewelry.

But fat people don’t just pay more—we also make less than our thinner counterparts.

The fat tax finds us in health care too. If we see a doctor who doesn’t dismiss our symptoms out of hand, brushing them off with a simple “just lose weight,” many of us will be required to seek care out-of-network and pay out-of-pocket just to access the same health care as thinner people.

Even if we get lucky and find a doctor in our network, equipment like MRIs and CT scanners are built for thin people. Often, fat patients shoulder the cost of finding, and traveling to, facilities that have equipment that fit our bodies. Fat people with disabilities pay hundreds more for wheelchairs, walkers, and crutches that support their fat bodies. And fat people who become pregnant may be saddled with the additional cost of an abortion or prenatal care because most emergency contraception doesn’t reliably work on bodies over 176 pounds.

These, it seems, are the costs of living in the only body I have ever had.

For many fat people, no matter how healthy our habits, life insurance will be out of the question, leaving us with fewer ways to care for our loved ones when we are gone. And they will face the fat tax too. Because even burying a fat person costs more, with standard size coffins running $2,000-$3,000, while plus size caskets cost up to $5,000 apiece.

But fat people don’t just pay more—we also make less than our thinner counterparts. Some studies show that fat people make $2,500 less than thin people each year. Others show that a woman who is just 13 pounds over her BMI-recommended weight makes $9,000 less annually than her thin colleagues. And when broken out by gender, the fat pay gap widens dramatically.

Multiple federal circuit court decisions have upheld employers’ right to both weigh employees and to fire them solely because of their size. Just three years ago, courts told 22 former “Borgata Babes”—casino servers who were subjected to random weigh-ins and suspensions for weight gain—that their employer’s policies were just fine, allowable under state and federal law, which does not provide even basic legal protections against size-based bias. Even the most overt size-based discrimination is perfectly legal in the United States.

Those of us fortunate and privileged enough to find steady employment with decent pay can be regularly set back by the costs of retention and advancement: second airline seats, checked bags, rental car upgrades, and more.

These, it seems, are the costs of living in the only body I have ever had.

Like so many conversations about fatness, requesting the accommodations I need feels like a fait accompli. My experience has been so reliably disappointing and isolating that I struggle to imagine anything changing. Every time I think of approaching human resources, I watch a rudimentary flip-book animation in my mind’s eye: My colleagues will happily take my requested meeting. We will talk pleasantly for a few minutes, all warmth and kindness. I will watch their faces fall as they come to understand what I am asking them for. And then, they will fall into the same trap as so many before them, ending the conversation with some variation on a callous phrase, cruel in its simplicity: “If you don’t like it, just lose weight.”

Just. As if their 10-pound New Year’s resolution obeyed the same rules my 240-pound loss would, should I try to meet my BMI-recommended weight.

Just. As if it were that easy to cut my body in half. As if it would take fewer than five years of uninterrupted and extreme dieting that would ultimately result in major weight gain and permanently damage my metabolism in the long term. As if diets even work—they don’t; 97% of diets fail. As if women my size had even a 1% chance of becoming thin. (We don’t—only 0.8% of very fat women will reach their BMI-recommended weight in their lifetime.)

Just. As if weight loss surgeries were covered by health insurance and wouldn’t cost $25K, plus the cost of follow-up procedures to remove excess skin. As if those surgeries didn’t have terrifying complications and change the way a person eats forever. As if this were a reasonable intervention into the fat tax—pay tens of thousands of dollars in surgery costs to pay the same rate as everyone else for clothing, travel, furniture.

Just. As if they knew.

As I write this, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 70% of Americans are “overweight” or “obese.” If we were in Congress, we would comprise a supermajority. If we were test scores, we would be a passing grade. We are not a niche market, nor can we be saved by the casual dismissal of just.

Overwhelmingly, the costs facing us are leveled by major corporations whose industries are growing, costs decreasing, and profit margins increasing. Airlines are expected to make $35.5 billion in profits this year, while the apparel industry is worth $292 billion. Their bottom lines are as strong as ever, even as so many of them seek solely to serve 30% of their potential customers—those whose thin bodies afford them the privilege of service. Corporate profits are doing fine, and they aren’t the question here.

Will we build that brave new world with the fat people we know and love?

The question here is the degree to which we are willing to create and exploit a growing wealth gap facing fat people across the country and around the world. Our fat friends and family already work less, earn less, and pay more, even for basic necessities. We are more likely to be fired, more likely to be overcharged, and more likely to face economic insecurity than our thinner counterparts.

Are we willing to tell our fat friends, family, neighbors, and co-workers that their systemic economic disenfranchisement is unavoidable, that the fat tax they pay is some natural consequence of their skin? Or will we build a world that works for all of us? Will we work to level the playing field that has been so skewed based on how our bodies look? Or will we sit idly by as fat people make less and less, build more and more debt, and lag behind our thinner peers, regardless of our skills, character, and work ethic?

Will we build that brave new world with the fat people we know and love? Or will we hang them out to dry for the simple, dismissive brush-off of just?

  • Feminism
  • Equality
  • Finance
  • Body

  • Your Fat Friend

    Medium member since Jul 2018

    Your Fat Friend writes about the social realities of living as a very fat person. www.yourfatfriend.com

  • Human Parts

    What it means to be

title: The Fat Tax Is Real—and It’s Getting Worse
content_html:
The Fat Tax Is Real—and It’s Getting Worse

Inflated prices, surcharges, and limited employment opportunities are expanding the wealth gap between fat and thin

Your Fat Friend
Apr 9

I am booking a work trip across the country. It should be a simple task: find a flight at a reasonable time, for a reasonable price, and purchase it. Those of us who don’t drive will have to pay more for bicycles that will bear us, since so many bikes only support 150 to 200 pounds.

Even clothing is a challenge, and ethically made clothing is almost entirely out of the question when it comes to plus and extended plus sizes. Even budget staples like Old Navy have dramatic price gaps. A pair of basic jeans in size 18 from the straight size women’s section costs $27. Jewelry, especially rings and bracelets, offers an extremely limited selection, often requiring a costly special order in fine jewelry and extraordinarily limited options for costume jewelry.

But fat people don’t just pay more—we also make less than our thinner counterparts.

These, it seems, are the costs of living in the only body I have ever had.

For many fat people, no matter how healthy our habits, life insurance will be out of the question, leaving us with fewer ways to care for our loved ones when we are gone. And they will face the fat tax too. Because even burying a fat person costs more, with standard size coffins running $2,000-$3,000, while plus size caskets cost up to $5,000 apiece.

But fat people don’t just pay more—we also make less than our thinner counterparts. Some studies show that fat people make $2,500 less than thin people each year. Others show that a woman who is just 13 pounds over her BMI-recommended weight makes $9,000 less annually than her thin colleagues. And when broken out by gender, the fat pay gap widens dramatically.

Multiple federal circuit court decisions have upheld employers’ right to both weigh employees and to fire them solely because of their size. Just three years ago, courts told 22 former “Borgata Babes”—casino servers who were subjected to random weigh-ins and suspensions for weight gain—that their employer’s policies were just fine, allowable under state and federal law, which does not provide even basic legal protections against size-based bias. Even the most overt size-based discrimination is perfectly legal in the United States.

Those of us fortunate and privileged enough to find steady employment with decent pay can be regularly set back by the costs of retention and advancement: second airline seats, checked bags, rental car upgrades, and more.

These, it seems, are the costs of living in the only body I have ever had.

Like so many conversations about fatness, requesting the accommodations I need feels like a fait accompli. My experience has been so reliably disappointing and isolating that I struggle to imagine anything changing. Every time I think of approaching human resources, I watch a rudimentary flip-book animation in my mind’s eye: My colleagues will happily take my requested meeting. We will talk pleasantly for a few minutes, all warmth and kindness. I will watch their faces fall as they come to understand what I am asking them for. And then, they will fall into the same trap as so many before them, ending the conversation with some variation on a callous phrase, cruel in its simplicity: “If you don’t like it, just lose weight.”

Just. As if their 10-pound New Year’s resolution obeyed the same rules my 240-pound loss would, should I try to meet my BMI-recommended weight.

Just. As if it were that easy to cut my body in half. As if it would take fewer than five years of uninterrupted and extreme dieting that would ultimately result in major weight gain and permanently damage my metabolism in the long term. As if diets even work—they don’t; 97% of diets fail. As if women my size had even a 1% chance of becoming thin. (We don’t—only 0.8% of very fat women will reach their BMI-recommended weight in their lifetime.)

Just. As if weight loss surgeries were covered by health insurance and wouldn’t cost $25K, plus the cost of follow-up procedures to remove excess skin. As if those surgeries didn’t have terrifying complications and change the way a person eats forever. As if this were a reasonable intervention into the fat tax—pay tens of thousands of dollars in surgery costs to pay the same rate as everyone else for clothing, travel, furniture.

Just. As if they knew.

As I write this, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 70% of Americans are “overweight” or “obese.” If we were in Congress, we would comprise a supermajority. If we were test scores, we would be a passing grade. We are not a niche market, nor can we be saved by the casual dismissal of just.

Overwhelmingly, the costs facing us are leveled by major corporations whose industries are growing, costs decreasing, and profit margins increasing. Airlines are expected to make $35.5 billion in profits this year, while the apparel industry is worth $292 billion. Their bottom lines are as strong as ever, even as so many of them seek solely to serve 30% of their potential customers—those whose thin bodies afford them the privilege of service. Corporate profits are doing fine, and they aren’t the question here.

Will we build that brave new world with the fat people we know and love?

The question here is the degree to which we are willing to create and exploit a growing wealth gap facing fat people across the country and around the world. Our fat friends and family already work less, earn less, and pay more, even for basic necessities. We are more likely to be fired, more likely to be overcharged, and more likely to face economic insecurity than our thinner counterparts.

Are we willing to tell our fat friends, family, neighbors, and co-workers that their systemic economic disenfranchisement is unavoidable, that the fat tax they pay is some natural consequence of their skin? Or will we build a world that works for all of us? Will we work to level the playing field that has been so skewed based on how our bodies look? Or will we sit idly by as fat people make less and less, build more and more debt, and lag behind our thinner peers, regardless of our skills, character, and work ethic?

Will we build that brave new world with the fat people we know and love? Or will we hang them out to dry for the simple, dismissive brush-off of just?
